DOC.brief_summary: Evaluation of the efficacy of postpartum 24 hour oxytocin infusion to reduce blood loss in patients with pre-eclampsia (PE)
DOC.brief_title: Postpartum Hemorrhage Prevention in Patients With Preeclampsia (PHP3 Study)
DOC.detailed_description: The overall goal of this study is to evaluate the efficacy of postpartum 24 hour oxytocin infusion as a prevention-oriented strategy to reduce blood loss in patients with pre-eclampsia (PE) in a blinded, placebo controlled, randomized controlled trial.
DOC.criteria: 1. vaginal or cesarean delivery at a gestational age greater than or equal to 20 weeks gestational age; 2. diagnosis of preeclampsia (PE defined using standard definitions based on the ACOG bulletin and the NIH Working Group on High Blood Pressure in Pregnancy (i.e., a systolic blood pressure greater than 140 mm Hg or a diastolic blood pressure greater than 90 mm Hg on at least 2 occasions at least 6 hours apart after 20 weeks gestation and proteinuria of > 300mg per 24 hour period or > 1+ on dipstick). 3. patients treated with magnesium sulfate for 24 hours post partum at 2g/hr (standard of care when deemed appropriate by clinician for seizure prophylaxis) 1. abnormal placentation (previa, accreta, etc) 2. antenatal hemorrhage 3. contraindication to oxytocin
